Conducted by Miss PIERCE & Mr BRACE.

 The Summer Term of this institution will commence an the 18th of May next.

reading to the aged sufferer. PeEhAps. my dear, you win write short narrative of her it would be a charming obituary; send tt tO me when it Is drawn zap, and will get it pab- Iished next month. Don't you think it would he very interesting. Mrs. Clifford '" she con- tinued, turning to her, before she had given Emma time to reply.

 Emma bit her lips to prevsa q smile, though the mention of Susan's name at other times, might more easily have drawn a tear to her eyes.

 Mrs. Clifford replied, " to us, who have so long witnessed her patient sufferings, every circumstance of Susan's death would be high ly interesting; but doubt whether it would be equally so to the public eye. Iagree with you, however, in thinking that Emma has been highly privileged in reading to her from that sacred volume, which has furnished the comfort and support of a long lie. In wit messing the triumph of a faith like Susan's, at once so humble and so strong, she has en- ioyed an opportunity of instruction, which may never again occur, and which, trust. she will not fail to improve"

 The clock now struck nine, and our morn ing visitor, starting from her seat, took a has ty leave. alleging, that she had long way to walk, and must be there by ten o'clock, for, fl she were not in time fer the prayer, ,sheshould have to stand all sermon time, as it would be impossible to obtain seat afterwards" Mrs. MdrshGU.

WHEREAS, LAVINA WOODRUFF w of Litchfeld, in said County, has brought her petition to this Court against her husband Salmon Woodruff, now residing in parts to her unknown, therein stating, among other things, that the said Salmon, at said Litchfeld, on or about the first day of July 1928, wilfulIy deserted her, and ever since has continued, and still continues, his desertion, residing out of this state, in the total neglect of all the duties of the marriage covenant, on hts part, to be performed, and praying fer a bill of divorce from the said Salmon, as her petition on file, dated the 5th day of Februa- ryl827.

 Orde1rd by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchfeld, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next and that the pendency of said petition, and copy of this order, be published six weeks successively, according to the statute in such case provided. in a paper printed in Litchfeld, called the Litchfeld County Post, and in pa. per printed in New Haven called the Colum bian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court,

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk.

 true Copy, 6w4S

Amos Barnum's Estate.

1S the EdttOr ot the ~. E. Farmer. Sr,-I observe in your last paper an ar- ticle relating to the destruction of the fruit

 blossoms of peach trees, and an assurance

 that they are already frost bitten, and black

 SO as to leave no hopes of crop of this de-

 lightful fruit this year any more than the

 last. I hope MT. Editor, that your corres-

 pondeni is mistaken, in regard to his facts. It would be uncommon to have them des- troyed two years in succession; and from

 the little observation have been able to

 make, think he is. It does not follow

 because number of the fruit blossoms are

 black in the centre, that all the fruit is des-

 troyed, for if one fourth part of the b]os-

 som buds which are annually formed on

 peach trees were to set fruit, the trees would be overloaded.

 have no doubt that the writer of the ar- ticle in question, is right in believing that the fruit buds are killed by the first severe frosts that set in during the winter, and not in the spring, as is generrlly supposed. l recollect that in the winter of 1856 there was sudden change in the temperature a. bout the middle of Dec. when the mercury fell to or 6 degrees below zero, from very temperate and delightful one that had existed during the greater part of the au- tumn and previous part of that month. I thent thought and said, that both the peach tees and fruit buds would be injured by it, -and it proved that both were very much injured the most of the young shoots of the preceding summers growth were killed in part, if not in whole and all the Efruit buds on the trees were destroyed. But it was said that this ravage ofthe peach trees took place about the 18th or 18th of April when the frost was veay severe for the sea- son. This'is mistake as I shall show you.

 In the first place it would be extraordin- ary indeed, that the wood and buds of tree that had stood through the whole win ter without being killed by cold from high { CT temperature by 20 or 25 degrees than they had already been exposed to; particu- iarly as both the wood and the buds are betterprepared to resist after having endur- ed it for twoor three months, than they are in the early part of the winter before the wood and buds had become ripe and hard enough to resist the cold.

 But there is another reason which is con. elusive, think, as to this fact. My peach house was left open during the winter uuiil March 18th. when shut it up. I then saw that the fruit buds on my trees were principally killed; and in fact had no fruit or but very few on my trees. Now. as mv house was shut up after March 18th. the fruit could not have been injured by the frost in April.

 Dry warm falls prepare the wood best to resist the severefrosts of winter. 1.-the early part of winter is dry and moderately cold, the wood and buds will bear severe frosts withoutinjury; but warm wet falls and early winter leave both the wood and buds unripe and very tender, as the sap in snch cases is kept in an active state. and of course IS more liable to be acted on by the frost than when the alburnum has becoma hard and woody; and the bark ripe and hard. 1t is advantageous therefore to brush oil the leaves of peach trees as soon as the hrst frost has attacked them in the fall, that the shoots and buds may be exposed to the sun and air as much as possible before the winter sets in. Yours. &c.

 March 27, 1926.
FRUIT TREES.

NOTICE.

Conducted by Miss PIERCE & Mr BRACE.

 The Summer Term of this institution will commence an the 18th of May next.

 TERMS.

 Tuition, per quarter of Ia weeks, dollars. Music, |" l2 French, " 3 Scholars in the lower branches are charged SIO GDr the term of twenty four weeks.

 The text books used are

 Murray's Grammar,-WOOdbridg Geog- raphy and Atlas,-Dabors or WilIett's Arith- metic,-Abridgemen of Blair's Rhetoric.- Conversations on Natural PhilOsophy,-dO. on Chemistry,-Paley's Moral Philosophy Hedges LOgic,-Al;sOn on Taste,-Abridge- ment of Universal History,-RusselPs Mod ern Europe, with COOte's Continuation, and GOOdrich's American History. The Latin & Greek languages, the Mathematical sciences, with any other studies, can be pursued at the option of the scholar.

 The Instructors hope that the long estab- lished reputation Ofthis Institution their ex- perience and attention to their duties; the beauty and healtfulness of the village oi Litchfeld; and polished manners and litera- ry character of its inhabitants, may author ise them to request the continuance of the public patronage. l Board can be obtained from gl,75 to $2,0C per week, exclusive of washing. Erpsllent Rules ssr prOmstisg harmOay 0moag

 ths Mem6srs efa chNroh.

 I. To remember that we are all subject to failings and infrmities of some kind or other.

 2. To bear with. and not magnify, each others sinfrnlities.-Gat. VI. l. Il

 s. TO prsy one for another in our social meetings, and particularly in private.-JGmes, v. I6.

 4. To avoid going from house to house, for the purpose of hearing news, and interfering with other persons business.

 :. Always to turn deaf ear to every slanderOus report. and to lay no charge, brought against any person, until we'll fOun- ded.

 6. If a member he in fault, to tell him of it io pripate, before it is mentioned to others.

 '. To watch against a shyness of each other, and to put the best construction on any action that has the appearance of oppo- sition or resentment.

 8. To observe the just rule of Solomon, that is, to leave off contention, before 1t be meddled with.-ProU. xvii. IA.

 g. If member has offended, to consider how glorious, how God-like it is, to forgive, and how unlike Christian it is to revenge.- Epk. iv. 9.

 10. To remember that it is always grand artifce of the devil to promote distance and animosity amongst members of churches; and we should therefore watch against every thing that furthers his end.

 II. To consider how much more good we can do in the world at large, and in the church in particular when we are all united in love, than we can do when acting alone, and indul- ginga contrary spirit.

 1c Lastly, to consider the express in lunc- tions of Scripture, and the beautiful example of Christ, as to these important things.-Eph. iv. Sa. Pet. ii. 21. John, Xiii. 5, S5.

 Am. Sent.

 Norratiw.-" We had not risen from the breakfast table one morning, when female, rather young, and fashionably dressed, enter ed the room. After few common place civiltes, she turned to Mrs. Clifford, saying. Il called to tell you that MT. S-- is in town; he breaches to-day at -, and you must positively put on your things, and go with me to hear him.'' "Could consistent ly do so,'' replied her friend, "I should be very happy to accompany. you; but, excuse me if l say, that were this excellent man to see the dear little group by which I am sur rounded, he would be the first to forbid my leaving them to listen to his sermon."

 Perhaps the conscious recollection of some duty unperformed at home. just then stung the feelings of our far devotee; or it might he purely misguided zeal, which reddened on her cheek, as she retorted, somewhat sharp ly, When, like Marthas, the heart is care full and troubled abovt many things, it is easy to find pretext of duty to prevent our listen ing to the words of Jesus."

 Mrs. Clifford mildly answered, "I hope I am aware of this plausible deception, but in the present instance l am not conscious of merting the rebuke. You may remember, my dear Mrs. Hammond, that Martha was not censured for necessary attention to her ordinary and relative duties but for an undue anxiety, an ostentatious and i'll timed desire of providing things, more than hospitably gOod.' Perhaps, too, may remind you, that there subsists visible difference between her negecting to hear the words of the Redee- { mer, when he honoured her roof with his sa- cred presence, and my declining to attend the discourse of one of his servants, when such l anattendance would necessarily involve neg lect of duties,more strictly enjoined upon me-" "You have always great deal to say about duties, my dear," resumed the lady, 6 but if 1 read my bible aright, no duties are SO accep. table with God, as an aifectionate reception of his gospel, and desire to see his kingdom advanced in our own hearts, and in the world around us." She then magnanimously de- clared her resolution to persist in her attach ment to the word preached, although it continued to expose her to many domestic sacrifices, and involved her in several uettv l prosecutions"

 believe Mrs. Clifford could have ey;nced to her fair friend, that she had not " read her bible arlght:" but as spirit of recrinination certainly was not the temper by which she sought to maintain the honor of religion, she thought it better to drop the subject, than to expose her visitor to the imminent risk of losing her temper.

 A short silence therefore ensued. till MT. Clifford inquired of Mrs. Hammond. 'wheth CT she had yet had an opportunity of visiting the sick woman, whose case he recommend ed to her 7" No, really" she replied. :" nave not had one moment of leisure since you named her to me. On Monday was at the Bible society's meeting; Tuesday, went to hear MT. - preach; Wednesday, | di. ned at MT. Nelson's, where select number ofserlous friends were assembled to meet the Rev: Mr. H----; all Thursday. ! was occupied ln endeavormg to procure subscri- bers to our Dorcas Society; and to-day. shall hardly have time to swallow my dinner. on my return home, before the arrival of lady who has promised to go with me to hear a sermon for the benefit of our Sunday School"

Ereellenf Rnles esr promoting harmOay amoMg

reading to the aged sufferer. PeEhAps. my dear, you win write short narrative of her it would be a charming obituary; send tt tO me when it Is drawn zap, and will get it pab- Iished next month. Don't you think it would he very interesting. Mrs. Clifford '" she con- tinued, turning to her, before she had given Emma time to reply.

 Emma bit her lips to prevsa q smile, though the mention of Susan's name at other times, might more easily have drawn a tear to her eyes.

 Mrs. Clifford replied, " to us, who have so long witnessed her patient sufferings, every circumstance of Susan's death would be high ly interesting; but doubt whether it would be equally so to the public eye. Iagree with you, however, in thinking that Emma has been highly privileged in reading to her from that sacred volume, which has furnished the comfort and support of a long lie. In wit messing the triumph of a faith like Susan's, at once so humble and so strong, she has en- ioyed an opportunity of instruction, which may never again occur, and which, trust. she will not fail to improve"

 The clock now struck nine, and our morn ing visitor, starting from her seat, took a has ty leave. alleging, that she had long way to walk, and must be there by ten o'clock, for, fl she were not in time fer the prayer, ,sheshould have to stand all sermon time, as it would be impossible to obtain seat afterwards" Mrs. MdrshGU.

 Orde1rd by this Court that said petition be continued to the next Term of this Court, to be holden at Litchfeld, within and for said County, on the third Tuesday of August next and that the pendency of said petition, and copy of this order, be published six weeks successively, according to the statute in such case provided. in a paper printed in Litchfeld, called the Litchfeld County Post, and in pa. per printed in New Haven called the Colum bian Register, which shall be sufficient notice to the said Salmon to appear and defend in said petition.

 By the Court,

 F. WOLCOTT, Clerk.

full articles.headline: FRUIT TREES.
full articles.article:
1S the EdttOr ot the ~. E. Farmer. Sr,-I observe in your last paper an ar- ticle relating to the destruction of the fruit

 blossoms of peach trees, and an assurance

 that they are already frost bitten, and black

 SO as to leave no hopes of crop of this de-

 lightful fruit this year any more than the

 last. I hope MT. Editor, that your corres-

 pondeni is mistaken, in regard to his facts. It would be uncommon to have them des- troyed two years in succession; and from

 the little observation have been able to

 make, think he is. It does not follow

 because number of the fruit blossoms are

 black in the centre, that all the fruit is des-

 troyed, for if one fourth part of the b]os-

 som buds which are annually formed on

 peach trees were to set fruit, the trees would be overloaded.

 have no doubt that the writer of the ar- ticle in question, is right in believing that the fruit buds are killed by the first severe frosts that set in during the winter, and not in the spring, as is generrlly supposed. l recollect that in the winter of 1856 there was sudden change in the temperature a. bout the middle of Dec. when the mercury fell to or 6 degrees below zero, from very temperate and delightful one that had existed during the greater part of the au- tumn and previous part of that month. I thent thought and said, that both the peach tees and fruit buds would be injured by it, -and it proved that both were very much injured the most of the young shoots of the preceding summers growth were killed in part, if not in whole and all the Efruit buds on the trees were destroyed. But it was said that this ravage ofthe peach trees took place about the 18th or 18th of April when the frost was veay severe for the sea- son. This'is mistake as I shall show you.

 In the first place it would be extraordin- ary indeed, that the wood and buds of tree that had stood through the whole win ter without being killed by cold from high { CT temperature by 20 or 25 degrees than they had already been exposed to; particu- iarly as both the wood and the buds are betterprepared to resist after having endur- ed it for twoor three months, than they are in the early part of the winter before the wood and buds had become ripe and hard enough to resist the cold.

 But there is another reason which is con. elusive, think, as to this fact. My peach house was left open during the winter uuiil March 18th. when shut it up. I then saw that the fruit buds on my trees were principally killed; and in fact had no fruit or but very few on my trees. Now. as mv house was shut up after March 18th. the fruit could not have been injured by the frost in April.

 Dry warm falls prepare the wood best to resist the severefrosts of winter. 1.-the early part of winter is dry and moderately cold, the wood and buds will bear severe frosts withoutinjury; but warm wet falls and early winter leave both the wood and buds unripe and very tender, as the sap in snch cases is kept in an active state. and of course IS more liable to be acted on by the frost than when the alburnum has becoma hard and woody; and the bark ripe and hard. 1t is advantageous therefore to brush oil the leaves of peach trees as soon as the hrst frost has attacked them in the fall, that the shoots and buds may be exposed to the sun and air as much as possible before the winter sets in. Yours. &c.

 March 27, 1926.

At Court of Probate, holden ct Ltchfieid

 sDithin and .tor the District of Litchfield, April l6th, 1897.

 Present FREDERICK WoLcoTT, Esq. Judge. TTPONth the Petition of Keziah Morgan, ,ofthe O town of Peru, in the County of Clinton and State of New ork showing to this Coul that she is the parent of Seth Bull, Jasper Bull, Fanny Bull and Clifford Bull, they all being Minors and Children of the Petitioner, by her late husband, Norman Bull, late of said town of Peru, but now deceased--that said Minors are the owners, and are possessed, as tenants in common with the other heirs at law ofthe said Norman, deceased, ofthe following described tracts of land, and the buildings thereon, situate in the town of Harwinton, in the County of Litchfeld in the State of Con necticut, Uiz :: of one undivided third part of one acre of land, with one third part of the buildings thereon, at the southeast corner of the home lot lately occupied by Sabra Cook, late of said HarwintOn, deceased-Also of a. bout four acres at the north side of said home ot;-that the interest of said Minors in said tracts ofland, came to them by descent thro' their said Father, Norman Bull, deceased. rom their grand mother, the said Sabra Cook deceased--praying liberty to sell said proper. ty, as her petition on file.

 This Court doth adjourn the consideration of said Petition until the 25th day of June next, at the Probate office in Litchfieid,i in said District, at ten o'clock in the forenoon: and doth order that notice thereof be given hv publishing the same in the newspaper printed in sad Liichfeld three weeks success;yclv st least six weeks before the said aSth of June next. A true Copy-of Record. Attest, FREDERICK WOLCOTT, Judge.

Town Meeting, legally soarned, and holden ir

 Warren October eSd, 18e6

 Voted, That all Horned Cattle, (except two from famly,) and all Horses Asses. Mules. and Sheep, shall be restrained from going at large on the Common OF Highway, in said town of Warren the year ensuing. And if any Horses, Mules and Sheep shall be found running at large, on the Common or High. way m said town the ensuing year, or more Horned Cattle than two from a family, and they with the mark of the owner on the ear. any, person shall have right to impound them m the same manner as is provided by law for the lmpounding of Horses, Cattle, Mules and Shetp' breaking into enclosures. full articles.headline:
LTTCHFIELD FEMALE

 ACADEMY,
full articles.article:
Conducted by Miss PIERCE & Mr BRACE.

 The Summer Term of this institution will commence an the 18th of May next.

 TERMS.

 Tuition, per quarter of Ia weeks, dollars. Music, |" l2 French, " 3 Scholars in the lower branches are charged SIO GDr the term of twenty four weeks.

 The text books used are

 Murray's Grammar,-WOOdbridg Geog- raphy and Atlas,-Dabors or WilIett's Arith- metic,-Abridgemen of Blair's Rhetoric.- Conversations on Natural PhilOsophy,-dO. on Chemistry,-Paley's Moral Philosophy Hedges LOgic,-Al;sOn on Taste,-Abridge- ment of Universal History,-RusselPs Mod ern Europe, with COOte's Continuation, and GOOdrich's American History. The Latin & Greek languages, the Mathematical sciences, with any other studies, can be pursued at the option of the scholar.

 The Instructors hope that the long estab- lished reputation Ofthis Institution their ex- perience and attention to their duties; the beauty and healtfulness of the village oi Litchfeld; and polished manners and litera- ry character of its inhabitants, may author ise them to request the continuance of the public patronage. l Board can be obtained from gl,75 to $2,0C per week, exclusive of washing. Litchfield, April 24, 1897.

full articles.headline:
Ereellenf Rnles esr promoting harmOay amoMg

 the Mcm5sFs ofa Charch.
full articles.article:
Erpsllent Rules ssr prOmstisg harmOay 0moag

 ths Mem6srs efa chNroh.

 I. To remember that we are all subject to failings and infrmities of some kind or other.

 2. To bear with. and not magnify, each others sinfrnlities.-Gat. VI. l. Il

 s. TO prsy one for another in our social meetings, and particularly in private.-JGmes, v. I6.

 4. To avoid going from house to house, for the purpose of hearing news, and interfering with other persons business.

 :. Always to turn deaf ear to every slanderOus report. and to lay no charge, brought against any person, until we'll fOun- ded.

 6. If a member he in fault, to tell him of it io pripate, before it is mentioned to others.

 '. To watch against a shyness of each other, and to put the best construction on any action that has the appearance of oppo- sition or resentment.

 8. To observe the just rule of Solomon, that is, to leave off contention, before 1t be meddled with.-ProU. xvii. IA.

 g. If member has offended, to consider how glorious, how God-like it is, to forgive, and how unlike Christian it is to revenge.- Epk. iv. 9.

 10. To remember that it is always grand artifce of the devil to promote distance and animosity amongst members of churches; and we should therefore watch against every thing that furthers his end.

 II. To consider how much more good we can do in the world at large, and in the church in particular when we are all united in love, than we can do when acting alone, and indul- ginga contrary spirit.

 1c Lastly, to consider the express in lunc- tions of Scripture, and the beautiful example of Christ, as to these important things.-Eph. iv. Sa. Pet. ii. 21. John, Xiii. 5, S5.

 Am. Sent.

 Norratiw.-" We had not risen from the breakfast table one morning, when female, rather young, and fashionably dressed, enter ed the room. After few common place civiltes, she turned to Mrs. Clifford, saying. Il called to tell you that MT. S-- is in town; he breaches to-day at -, and you must positively put on your things, and go with me to hear him.'' "Could consistent ly do so,'' replied her friend, "I should be very happy to accompany. you; but, excuse me if l say, that were this excellent man to see the dear little group by which I am sur rounded, he would be the first to forbid my leaving them to listen to his sermon."

 Perhaps the conscious recollection of some duty unperformed at home. just then stung the feelings of our far devotee; or it might he purely misguided zeal, which reddened on her cheek, as she retorted, somewhat sharp ly, When, like Marthas, the heart is care full and troubled abovt many things, it is easy to find pretext of duty to prevent our listen ing to the words of Jesus."

 Mrs. Clifford mildly answered, "I hope I am aware of this plausible deception, but in the present instance l am not conscious of merting the rebuke. You may remember, my dear Mrs. Hammond, that Martha was not censured for necessary attention to her ordinary and relative duties but for an undue anxiety, an ostentatious and i'll timed desire of providing things, more than hospitably gOod.' Perhaps, too, may remind you, that there subsists visible difference between her negecting to hear the words of the Redee- { mer, when he honoured her roof with his sa- cred presence, and my declining to attend the discourse of one of his servants, when such l anattendance would necessarily involve neg lect of duties,more strictly enjoined upon me-" "You have always great deal to say about duties, my dear," resumed the lady, 6 but if 1 read my bible aright, no duties are SO accep. table with God, as an aifectionate reception of his gospel, and desire to see his kingdom advanced in our own hearts, and in the world around us." She then magnanimously de- clared her resolution to persist in her attach ment to the word preached, although it continued to expose her to many domestic sacrifices, and involved her in several uettv l prosecutions"

 believe Mrs. Clifford could have ey;nced to her fair friend, that she had not " read her bible arlght:" but as spirit of recrinination certainly was not the temper by which she sought to maintain the honor of religion, she thought it better to drop the subject, than to expose her visitor to the imminent risk of losing her temper.

 A short silence therefore ensued. till MT. Clifford inquired of Mrs. Hammond. 'wheth CT she had yet had an opportunity of visiting the sick woman, whose case he recommend ed to her 7" No, really" she replied. :" nave not had one moment of leisure since you named her to me. On Monday was at the Bible society's meeting; Tuesday, went to hear MT. - preach; Wednesday, | di. ned at MT. Nelson's, where select number ofserlous friends were assembled to meet the Rev: Mr. H----; all Thursday. ! was occupied ln endeavormg to procure subscri- bers to our Dorcas Society; and to-day. shall hardly have time to swallow my dinner. on my return home, before the arrival of lady who has promised to go with me to hear a sermon for the benefit of our Sunday School"
